title-group.article-title: Shifts in the Microbial Community Composition of Gulf Coast Beaches following Beach Oiling
title-group.alt-title: Oil Impact on Beach Bacterial Communities

aff.institution: Department of Pathology and Laboratory Medicine
School of Freshwater Sciences, Great Lakes WATER Institute

abstract.p: Microorganisms associated with coastal sands serve as a natural biofilter, providing essential nutrient recycling in nearshore environments and acting to maintain coastal ecosystem health. Anthropogenic stressors often impact these ecosystems, but little is known about whether these disturbances can be identified through microbial community change. The blowout of the Macondo Prospect reservoir on April 20, 2010, which released oil hydrocarbons into the Gulf of Mexico, presented an opportunity to examine whether microbial community composition might provide a sensitive measure of ecosystem disturbance. Samples were collected on four occasions, beginning in mid-June, during initial beach oiling, until mid-November from surface sand and surf zone waters at seven beaches stretching from Bay St. Louis, MS to St. George Island, FL USA. Oil hydrocarbon measurements and NOAA shoreline assessments indicated little to no impact on the two most eastern beaches (controls). Sequence comparisons of bacterial ribosomal RNA gene hypervariable regions isolated from beach sands located to the east and west of Mobile Bay in Alabama demonstrated that regional drivers account for markedly different bacterial communities. Individual beaches had unique community signatures that persisted over time and exhibited spatial relationships, where community similarity decreased as horizontal distance between samples increased from one to hundreds of meters. In contrast, sequence analyses detected larger temporal and less spatial variation among the water samples. Superimposed upon these beach community distance and time relationships, was increased variability in bacterial community composition from oil hydrocarbon contaminated sands. The increased variability was observed among the core, resident, and transient community members, indicating the occurrence of community-wide impacts rather than solely an overprinting of oil hydrocarbon-degrading bacteria onto otherwise relatively stable sand population structures. Among sequences classified to genus, Alcanivorax, Alteromonas, Marinobacter, Winogradskyella, and Zeaxanthinibacter exhibited the largest relative abundance increases in oiled sands.

Dual Publication

Direct Billing to Institutions and Funders
The institutions or funding agencies listed below have agreed to be invoiced directly and cover publication fees in PLoS Journals for their affiliated researchers. If you are a corresponding author affiliated with one of the organizations listed, please select it. If you are funded by a funding agency or institution but are not affiliated with that agency or institution, please leave this section blank.

Institutional Membership Discount
An author's institution, funding agency, or even country may have an arrangement with PLoS, such as an Institutional Membership, to offset all or part of the publication cost. If you are entitled to the benefits of such an arrangement, your institution or funding agency will be included in the list of organizations below. Please click your institution's or funding agency's name to display the percentage discount off of the full publication charge. This discount will be calculated for you in the event that your manuscript is accepted for publication.

To be eligible for this publication discount you must be the corresponding author affiliated with the member institution.

Publication Fees and Global Participation Initiative

PLOS is committed to the widest possible global participation in open access publishing. To determine the appropriate fee, we use a country-based pricing model, which is based on the country that provides 50% or more of the primary funding for the research that is being submitted.

Research articles funded by Upper Middle and High Income Countries incur our standard publication fees; fees for Low and Lower Middle Income Countries are calculated according to the PLOS Global Participation Initiative pricing program for manuscripts submitted after 9am Pacific Time on September 4, 2012 (this program is not retroactive):

 I. Upper Middle and High Income Countries

  These countries will be automatically charged our standard publication fees (no price increases since 2009) as follows:

  • PLOS Biology US$2900
  • PLOS Medicine US$2900
  • PLOS Computational Biology US$2250
  • PLOS Genetics US$2250
  • PLOS Pathogens US$2250
  • PLOS Neglected Tropical Diseases US$2250
  • PLOS ONE US$1350

 II. Low and Lower Middle Income countries – PLOS Global Participation Initiative

  Group One: Countries from this list will not be charged for publishing

  Group Two: Countries from this list will be charged a flat $500

You will receive an invoice for the appropriate publication fee upon acceptance of your manuscript for publication. We will not invoice manuscripts that qualify for no charge under the Global Participation Initiative.

If you have further questions on our country-based pricing model, please review this FAQ.

All pricing programs are subject to change.

Fee Waivers

Our fee waiver policy, whereby PLOS offers to waive or further reduce the payment required of authors who cannot pay the full amount charged for publication, remains in effect. Editors and reviewers have no access to whether authors are able to pay; decisions to publish are only based on editorial criteria.

We will only invoice you when your manuscript is accepted. At that time you can request a full or partial fee waiver with your explanation for requiring a waiver. We will not invoice manuscripts that qualify for no charge under the Global Participation Initiative.

All waiver programs are subject to change.

Funding Statement

Please tell us from which country the research in this submission is primarily funded

Why am I being asked this question? PLOS uses country-based pricing to calculate your publication fee. We do this based on the country that you identified as the primary funder for the submission. By this we mean the country that funds the largest proportion of research conducted for this submission; we recognize that this may not be the country that funds the corresponding author. You will receive an invoice for the appropriate publication fee upon acceptance of your manuscript for publication.
